page.title: 04Railway
page.content: This single line section of the Waterloo to London line was once renowned for the steepness of its incline - often necessitating an extra engine being added to the train at Seton Junction. With modern diesel engines and shorter trains there now appears to be no problem. After crossing the flood plains of the River Axe this section of the line is very attractive being built on the slope of the hill above the Umborne Brook. There is not a great deal of traffic on this line as the Exeter-Paddington line is considered to be the major rail route from London to the south west. In Victorian times, especially at Bank holiday times, this line was very busy with day trippers going to Seaton and alighting at the long closed Seaton Junction station at nearby Shute.
